nodes.text: Conventional ex-ante cost-benefit analysis (CBA) of public investments is based on the assumption that cost and benefit estimates are accurate and unbiased; we hypothesize this assumption is false and that biased estimates systematically mislead resource allocation

Dataset and sampling method: a curated dataset of 2,062 public investment projects (eight investment types, 104 countries, 1927-2013) built from documentary sources and previous studies; tests run on full sample and on subsample of 327 with both cost and benefit data

Result on cost estimates: cost overruns are common, biased upward, fat-tailed, and highly significant (average cost overrun ranges e.g., roads 1.24, dams 1.96; skewness and kurtosis show extreme right tail; Wilcoxon p < 0.0001)

Result on benefit estimates: benefit forecasts are often biased downward in realization (benefit overrun < 1 for many types, e.g., BRT 0.42, rail 0.66), statistically skewed and fat-tailed (Wilcoxon p < 0.001), though less extreme than cost data

Claim: Cost underestimation and benefit overestimation compound rather than cancel, producing systematically overestimated benefit-cost ratios (overestimation roughly 50 to 200 percent depending on type) and causing resource misallocation
Result: Bias persists over time and across geographies and investment types; Bayesian and conventional tests find few meaningful differences and no reduction in bias historically

Evidence: Statistical support includes Wilcoxon tests rejecting symmetry around one, D'Agostino skewness and Anscombe-Glynn kurtosis tests showing heavy tails, Mann-Whitney tests rejecting compensation hypothesis, and Bayesian checks using MCMC/JAGS confirming results

Evidence and examples: majority (about 80 percent) of investments show cost overrun not compensated by benefit overrun; a minority of projects do compensate but aggregate tests show they do not make up for the majority (Mann-Whitney p = 0.001)

Methodological choices and proxies: costs measured as recorded outturn construction/capital costs, benefits proxied by first-year benefits (or nearest available), estimated values taken at final investment decision; data inclusion required documentary support

Claim: Behavioral root causes explain bias—optimism bias, planning fallacy, overconfidence, probability neglect, and strategic misrepresentation lead planners to underestimate risks (schedule, geology, price) and overestimate mitigation

Claim: To correct the cost-benefit fallacy CBA practice must be reformed via four measures: systematic de-biasing, skin-in-the-game incentives for forecasters, independent audits, and adaptation to democratic decision contexts

Method/Claim: Reference class forecasting (the outside view) using empirical distributional error information is an effective, systematic de-biasing method and has been implemented and evaluated positively in multiple countries and studies
Claim: Introduce incentives and accountability (skin-in-the-game, legal or contractual consequences) so forecasters have reasons to produce accurate unbiased estimates
Claim: Independent, politically insulated audits and transparency are required to ensure methods and incentives work and to prevent politically motivated distortion of forecasts
Claim: CBA must be integrated into messy democratic decision making by combining expert analysis with public concerns rather than relying solely on technocratic, top-down expert-driven processes

Conclusion: Empirical evidence shows a pervasive 'cost-benefit fallacy'—CBA as currently practiced is highly misleading and can be worse than useless; adopting behavioral de-biasing, incentives, audits, and democratic integration is necessary to restore CBA's usefulness
